results.title: The Industrial revolution: beginnings in the United States
results.creator_credit: Dennis Azzarella, Lee Kohns, John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Traces the explosive growth of the Inudstrial Revolution in the United States - beginning with a thread mill built in 1791, followed by the first modern factory in history. Explains how labor-saving machines, mass production techniques, rapid communication devices increased the standard of living and how the development of fast transportation made the whole continent a market place. Part of the Rise of Industrial America series.

results.title: The Industrial revolution
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Hugh Baddeley Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the industrial developments that transformed the cottage industries of the eighteenth century into the power-driven factories of the nineteenth century. Describes development of the steam-engine, inventions in the textile industry and developments in communications and transport.

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, John Grierson, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: Industrial beginnings in West Pakistan
results.brief_description: In response to a rapid expansion in population the Pakistani government has sought the aid of foreign technicians and advisers to widen the labour market through the development of new industrial products. Their goal is twofold: to utilise the ancient skills of Pakistani craftsmen and to train the masses of unskilled workers to meet the demands of modern technology.

results.title: Indonesia: an Alternative Lifestyle
results.creator_credit: Leigh Tilson and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: A non-narrated film that contrasts behind-the-scenes life in both rural and urban Indonesia with the view of the country as seen by foreign tourists.

results.title: India: urban conditions
results.brief_description: Shows the effect of rapid population growth in Indian cities, particularly Calcutta, when rural workers migrate to the cities in an attempt to find work and feed their families. By studying the family of Sarat we learn of the problems of low wages, lack of work, inadequate housing and clothing, undernourishment and little or no education.

results.title: Including me. Parts I and II
results.creator_credit: Linda Janower and Indiana University. Audio Visual Center
results.brief_description: Part I documents some of the problems encountered by handicapped individuals and explains how recent Federal legislation can help them find school programs appropriate to their needs. Part II focuses on four handicapped individuals who have succeeded in making progress in educational settings.

results.title: The Incised image
results.brief_description: A film on the work of Charles Lloyd showing in detail the dry-point technique of etching and the possibilities of one-plate colour printing which he studied at Atelier 17 in Paris. Culminates in an animated sequence interpreting his statement - “each print is an adventure, a little journey of discovery”. The commentary is edited from his recorded discussions.

results.title: In search of myself
results.brief_description: Considers the conflicts encountered by the people of the emerging nations who want to utilise the best aspects of technologically advanced societies but also want their progress to be uniquely African in nature. Young Nigerian authors, artists and musicians discuss their opinions and experiences.
